# Succession to the British throne

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

![Changes must be reviewed before being displayed on this
page.](/w/extensions/FlaggedRevs/frontend/modules/img/doc-
magnify.png)![show/hide
details](/w/extensions/FlaggedRevs/frontend/modules/img/arrow-down.png)

This is the [latest accepted revision](/wiki/Wikipedia:Pending_changes
"Wikipedia:Pending changes"),
[reviewed](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:Log&type=review&page=Succession_to_the_British_throne)
on _27 March 2018_.

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Sovereign%27s_Throne.jpg/220px-
Sovereign%27s_Throne.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sovereign%27s_Throne.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sovereign%27s_Throne.jpg "Enlarge")

The Sovereign's Throne in the [House of Lords](/wiki/House_of_Lords "House of
Lords"), from which [the speech](/wiki/Speech_from_the_throne "Speech from the
throne") is delivered at [State Openings of
Parliament](/wiki/State_Openings_of_Parliament "State Openings of Parliament")

**Succession to the British throne** is determined by descent, gender (for
people born before October 2011), legitimacy, and religion. Under [common
law](/wiki/Common_law "Common law"), the Crown is inherited by a sovereign's
children or by a childless sovereign's nearest collateral line. The [Bill of
Rights 1689](/wiki/Bill_of_Rights_1689 "Bill of Rights 1689") and the [Act of
Settlement 1701](/wiki/Act_of_Settlement_1701 "Act of Settlement 1701"),
restrict succession to the [throne](/wiki/Throne "Throne") to the legitimate
Protestant descendants of [Sophia of Hanover](/wiki/Sophia_of_Hanover "Sophia
of Hanover") that are in "[communion](/wiki/Communion_\(Christian\) "Communion
\(Christian\)") with the [Church of England](/wiki/Church_of_England "Church
of England")".[1] Spouses of [Roman Catholics](/wiki/Roman_Catholics "Roman
Catholics") were disqualified from 1689 until the law was amended in 2015.
Protestant descendants of those excluded for being Roman Catholics are
eligible.[2]

Queen [Elizabeth II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II") is the sovereign, and
her [heir apparent](/wiki/Heir_apparent "Heir apparent") is her eldest son,
[Charles, Prince of Wales](/wiki/Charles,_Prince_of_Wales "Charles, Prince of
Wales"). Next in line after him is [Prince William, Duke of
Cambridge](/wiki/Prince_William,_Duke_of_Cambridge "Prince William, Duke of
Cambridge"), the Prince of Wales's elder son. Third in line is [Prince
George](/wiki/Prince_George_of_Cambridge "Prince George of Cambridge"), the
son of the Duke of Cambridge, followed by his sister, [Princess
Charlotte](/wiki/Princess_Charlotte_of_Cambridge "Princess Charlotte of
Cambridge"). Fifth in line is [Prince Henry of
Wales](/wiki/Prince_Henry_of_Wales "Prince Henry of Wales"), the younger son
of the Prince of Wales. Sixth in line is [Prince Andrew, Duke of
York](/wiki/Prince_Andrew,_Duke_of_York "Prince Andrew, Duke of York"), the
Queen's second-eldest son. Any of the first six in line marrying without the
sovereign's consent would be disqualified from succession.

The first four individuals in the line of succession who are over 21, and the
sovereign's consort, may be appointed [Counsellors of
State](/wiki/Counsellor_of_State "Counsellor of State"). Counsellors of State
perform some of the sovereign's duties in the United Kingdom while he or she
is out of the country or temporarily incapacitated. Otherwise, individuals in
the line of succession need not have specific legal or official roles.

The United Kingdom is one of the 16 [Commonwealth
realms](/wiki/Commonwealth_realm "Commonwealth realm"). Each of those
countries has the same person as monarch and the same order of succession. In
2011, the prime ministers of the realms [agreed
unanimously](/wiki/Perth_Agreement "Perth Agreement") to adopt a common
approach to amending the rules on the succession to their respective
[Crowns](/wiki/The_Crown "The Crown") so that absolute primogeniture would
apply for persons born after the date of the agreement, instead of [male-
preference primogeniture](/wiki/Male-preference_primogeniture "Male-preference
primogeniture"), and the ban on marriages to Roman Catholics would be lifted,
but the monarch would still need to be in communion with the [Church of
England](/wiki/Church_of_England "Church of England"). After the necessary
legislation had been enacted in accordance with each realm's constitution, the
changes took effect on 26 March 2015.

No official, complete version of the line of succession is currently
maintained. The exact number, in remoter collateral lines, of the persons who
would be eligible is uncertain. In 2001 genealogist [William Addams
Reitwiesner](/wiki/William_Addams_Reitwiesner "William Addams Reitwiesner")
compiled a list of 4,973 living descendants of the [Electress
Sophia](/wiki/Sophia_of_Hanover "Sophia of Hanover") in order of succession,
but did so disregarding Roman Catholic status.[3] When updated in January
2011, the number was more than five thousand.[4]

## History

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Succession_to_the_British_throne&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(May 2015)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
The current succession law in the United Kingdom evolved from succession law
in both England and Scotland. Originally in both countries, there were no
fixed rules governing succession to the throne. The individual could have
relied on inheritance, statute, election (by
[Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Great_Britain "Parliament of Great Britain")
or by another body), nomination (by a reigning sovereign in his or her
[will](/wiki/Will_\(law\) "Will \(law\)")), conquest or prescription (_de
facto_ possession of the Crown). It was often unclear which of these bases
should take precedence; often, the outcome depended not on the legal strength
of the claims, but on the political or military power of the claimants.

However, over time, the default rule became male primogeniture: later monarchs
coming to the throne by exception to this rule went to great lengths to
explain and justify going against these rules, and to prove their rivals
illegitimate. Eventually, Parliament asserted control of succession.

### England

In 1485, Henry Tudor, a female-line descendant of a legitimated branch of the
[royal house](/wiki/Royal_house "Royal house") of
[Lancaster](/wiki/House_of_Lancaster "House of Lancaster"), the [House of
Beaufort](/wiki/House_of_Beaufort "House of Beaufort"), assumed the English
crown as [Henry VII](/wiki/Henry_VII_of_England "Henry VII of England"), after
defeating [Richard III](/wiki/Richard_III_of_England "Richard III of
England"), who was killed at the [battle of
Bosworth](/wiki/Battle_of_Bosworth_Field "Battle of Bosworth Field") when
leading a charge against Henry's standard. Richard was the last king of the
[House of York](/wiki/House_of_York "House of York"), and the last of the
[Plantagenet dynasty](/wiki/House_of_Plantagenet "House of Plantagenet").
Henry declared himself king retroactively from 21 August 1485, the day before
his victory over Richard at Bosworth Field,[6] and caused Richard's _[Titulus
Regius](/wiki/Titulus_Regius "Titulus Regius")_ to be repealed and expunged
from the [Rolls of Parliament](/wiki/Rolls_of_Parliament "Rolls of
Parliament").[7] After Henry's coronation in London in October that year, his
first parliament, summoned to meet at Westminster in November, enacted that
"the inheritance of the crown should be, rest, remain and abide in the most
royal person of the then sovereign lord, King Henry VII, and the heirs of his
body lawfully coming."[8]

Henry VII was followed by his son, [Henry VIII](/wiki/Henry_VIII_of_England
"Henry VIII of England"). Though his father descended from the Lancastrians,
Henry VIII could also claim the throne through the Yorkist line, as his mother
[Elizabeth](/wiki/Elizabeth_of_York "Elizabeth of York") was the sister and
heiress of [Edward V](/wiki/Edward_V_of_England "Edward V of England"). In
1542 Henry also assumed the title [King of Ireland](/wiki/King_of_Ireland
"King of Ireland"); this would pass down with the monarchs of England, and
later Great Britain, until the [Acts of Union 1800](/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1800
"Acts of Union 1800") merged the separate crowns into that of the United
Kingdom.

Henry VIII's numerous marriages led to several complications over succession.
Henry VIII was first married to [Catherine of
Aragon](/wiki/Catherine_of_Aragon "Catherine of Aragon"), by whom he had a
daughter named [Mary](/wiki/Mary_I_of_England "Mary I of England"). His second
marriage, to [Anne Boleyn](/wiki/Anne_Boleyn "Anne Boleyn"), resulted in a
daughter named [Elizabeth](/wiki/Elizabeth_I_of_England "Elizabeth I of
England"). Henry VIII had a son, [Edward](/wiki/Edward_VI_of_England "Edward
VI of England"), by his third wife, [Jane Seymour](/wiki/Jane_Seymour "Jane
Seymour"). An Act of Parliament passed in 1533 declared Mary illegitimate;
another passed in 1536 did the same for Elizabeth. Though the two remained
illegitimate, an Act of Parliament passed in 1544 allowed reinserting them,
providing further "that the King should and might give, will, limit, assign,
appoint or dispose the said imperial Crown and the other premises … by
[letters patent](/wiki/Letters_patent "Letters patent") or last will in
writing." Mary and Elizabeth, under [Henry VIII's
will](/wiki/Will_of_Henry_VIII_of_England "Will of Henry VIII of England"),
were to be followed by descendants of the King's deceased sister [Mary Tudor,
Duchess of Suffolk](/wiki/Mary_Tudor,_Queen_of_France "Mary Tudor, Queen of
France") (he however excluded his niece [Frances Brandon, Duchess of
Suffolk](/wiki/Frances_Grey,_Duchess_of_Suffolk "Frances Grey, Duchess of
Suffolk")). This will also excluded from the succession the descendants of
Henry's eldest sister [Margaret Tudor](/wiki/Margaret_Tudor "Margaret Tudor"),
who were the rulers of [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Elizabeth_I_in_Parliament.jpg/170px-
Elizabeth_I_in_Parliament.jpg)](/wiki/File:Elizabeth_I_in_Parliament.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Elizabeth_I_in_Parliament.jpg "Enlarge")

Queen Elizabeth I enthroned in Parliament

When Henry VIII died in 1547, the young Edward succeeded him, becoming Edward
VI. Edward VI was the first Protestant Sovereign to succeed to the rule of
England. He attempted to divert the course of succession in his will to
prevent his Catholic half-sister, Mary, from inheriting the throne. He
excluded Mary and Elizabeth, settling on the Duchess of Suffolk's daughter,
[Lady Jane Grey](/wiki/Lady_Jane_Grey "Lady Jane Grey"). Jane was also
originally excluded on the premise that no woman could reign over England.
Nonetheless, the will, which originally referred to Jane's heirs-male, was
amended to refer to Jane _and_ her heirs-male. Upon Edward VI's death in 1553,
Jane was proclaimed Queen of England and Ireland. She was not universally
recognised and after nine days she was overthrown by the popular Mary. As
Henry VIII's will had been approved by an Act of Parliament in 1544, Edward's
contravening will was unlawful and ignored.

Mary was succeeded by her half-sister, Elizabeth, who broke with the
precedents of many of her predecessors, and refused to name an heir. Whilst
previous monarchs (including Henry VIII) had specifically been granted
authority to settle uncertain successions in their wills, the [Treasons Act
1571](/wiki/Treasons_Act_1571 "Treasons Act 1571") asserted that Parliament
had the right to settle disputes, and made it treason to deny Parliamentary
authority. Wary of threats from other possible heirs, Parliament further
passed the Act of Association 1584, which provided that any individual
involved in attempts to murder the Sovereign would be disqualified from
succeeding. (The Act was repealed in 1863.)

### Scotland

The [House of Stewart](/wiki/House_of_Stuart "House of Stuart") (later Stuart)
had ruled in Scotland since 1371. It had followed strict rules of
primogeniture until the deposition and exile of [Mary
I](/wiki/Mary,_Queen_of_Scots "Mary, Queen of Scots") in 1567; even then she
was succeeded by her son, [James VI](/wiki/James_VI_and_I "James VI and I").

### After the union of the crowns

#### Stuarts

Elizabeth I of England and Ireland was succeeded by King [James VI of
Scotland](/wiki/James_VI_and_I "James VI and I"), her first cousin twice
removed, even though his succession violated Henry VIII's will, under which
[Lady Anne Stanley](/wiki/Anne_Stanley,_Countess_of_Castlehaven "Anne Stanley,
Countess of Castlehaven"), heiress of Mary Tudor, Duchess of Suffolk, was
supposed to succeed. James asserted that hereditary right was superior to
statutory provision, and as King of Scotland was powerful enough to deter any
rival. He reigned as James I of England and Ireland, thus effecting the [Union
of the Crowns](/wiki/Union_of_the_Crowns "Union of the Crowns"), although
England and Scotland remained separate sovereign states until 1707. His
succession was rapidly ratified by Parliament.[9]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/6e/House_of_Stuart.png/850px-
House_of_Stuart.png)](/wiki/File:House_of_Stuart.png)

[](/wiki/File:House_of_Stuart.png "File:House of Stuart.png")

center

James's eldest surviving son and successor, [Charles
I](/wiki/Charles_I_of_England "Charles I of England"), was overthrown and
beheaded in 1649. The monarchy itself was abolished. A few years later, it was
replaced by the Protectorate under [Oliver Cromwell](/wiki/Oliver_Cromwell
"Oliver Cromwell"), effectively a monarch with the title of [Lord
Protector](/wiki/Lord_Protector "Lord Protector") rather than King. Cromwell
had the right to name his own successor, which he exercised on his deathbed by
choosing his son, [Richard Cromwell](/wiki/Richard_Cromwell "Richard
Cromwell"). Richard was ineffective, and was quickly forced from office.
Shortly afterwards, the monarchy was restored, with Charles I's son [Charles
II](/wiki/Charles_II_of_England "Charles II of England") as King.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Anniex.jpg/170px-
Anniex.jpg)](/wiki/File:Anniex.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Anniex.jpg "Enlarge")

After the death of her last child in 1700, [Princess
Anne](/wiki/Anne,_Queen_of_Great_Britain "Anne, Queen of Great Britain")
became the last individual left in the line of succession determined by the
Bill of Rights.

[James II and VII](/wiki/James_II_of_England "James II of England"), a Roman
Catholic, followed his brother Charles II, despite efforts in the late 1670s
to [exclude](/wiki/Exclusion_Crisis "Exclusion Crisis") him in favour of
Charles's illegitimate Protestant son, the [Duke of
Monmouth](/wiki/James_Scott,_1st_Duke_of_Monmouth "James Scott, 1st Duke of
Monmouth"). James was deposed when his Protestant opponents forced him to flee
from England in 1688. Parliament then deemed that James had, by fleeing the
realms, abdicated the thrones and offered the Crowns not to the King's infant
son [James](/wiki/James_Francis_Edward_Stuart "James Francis Edward Stuart")
but to his Protestant daughter [Mary](/wiki/Mary_II_of_England "Mary II of
England") and to her husband [William](/wiki/William_III_of_England "William
III of England"), who as James's nephew was the first person in the succession
not descended from him. The two became joint Sovereigns (a unique circumstance
in British history) as William III of England and Ireland (and II of Scotland)
and Mary II of England, Scotland and Ireland. William had insisted on this
unique provision as a condition of his military leadership against James.

The English [Bill of Rights](/wiki/Bill_of_Rights_1689 "Bill of Rights 1689")
passed in 1689 determined succession to the English, Scottish and Irish
Thrones. First in the line were the descendants of Mary II. Next came Mary's
sister [Princess Anne](/wiki/Anne,_Queen_of_Great_Britain "Anne, Queen of
Great Britain") and her descendants. Finally, the descendants of William by
any future marriage were added to the line of succession. Only Protestants
were allowed to succeed to the Thrones, and those who married Roman Catholics
were excluded.

After Mary II died in 1694, her husband continued to reign alone until his own
death in 1702. The line of succession provided for by the Bill of Rights was
almost at an end; William and Mary never had any children, and Princess Anne's
children had all died. Therefore, Parliament passed the [Act of
Settlement](/wiki/Act_of_Settlement_1701 "Act of Settlement 1701"). The Act
maintained the provision of the Bill of Rights whereby William would be
succeeded by Princess Anne and her descendants, and thereafter by his own
descendants from future marriages. The Act, however, declared that they would
be followed by James I & VI's granddaughter [Sophia](/wiki/Sophia_of_Hanover
"Sophia of Hanover"), Electress Dowager of Hanover (the daughter of James's
daughter [Elizabeth Stuart](/wiki/Elizabeth_Stuart,_Queen_of_Bohemia
"Elizabeth Stuart, Queen of Bohemia")), and her heirs. As under the Bill of
Rights, non-Protestants and those who married Roman Catholics were excluded.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Kurfuerstin_Sophie.JPG/170px-
Kurfuerstin_Sophie.JPG)](/wiki/File:Kurfuerstin_Sophie.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Kurfuerstin_Sophie.JPG "Enlarge")

Electress Sophia of Hanover (1630–1714)

Upon William's death, Anne became Queen of England, Scotland and Ireland.
Because the Parliament of England settled on Sophia as Anne's heir-presumptive
without consulting Scottish leaders, the [Estates of
Scotland](/wiki/Estates_of_Scotland "Estates of Scotland") retaliated by
passing the Scottish [Act of Security](/wiki/Act_of_Security "Act of
Security"). The Act provided that, upon the death of Anne, the Estates would
meet to select an heir to the throne of Scotland, who could not be the same
person as the English Sovereign unless numerous political and economic
conditions were met. Anne originally withheld the [Royal
Assent](/wiki/Royal_Assent "Royal Assent"), but was forced to grant it when
the Estates refused to raise taxes and sought to withdraw troops from the
Queen's army. England's Parliament responded by passing the [Alien Act
1705](/wiki/Alien_Act_1705 "Alien Act 1705"), which threatened to cripple
Scotland's economy by cutting off trade with them. Thus, Scotland had little
choice but to unite with England to form the [Kingdom of Great
Britain](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain "Kingdom of Great Britain") in 1707;
the Crown of the new nation (along with the Crown of Ireland) was subject to
the rules laid down by the English Act of Settlement.

#### Hanoverians and Windsors

[![Title page, which is crowded with fonts of varying sizes and shapes, reads
"The Protestant Tutor, Instructing YOUTH, and Others, In the Compleat Method
of Spelling, Reading, and Writing True English; Also, Discovering to them the
Notorious ERRORS, Damnable DOCTRINES, and Cruel MASSACRES, of the Bloddy
Papists; Which England may Expect from a Popish Successor. With Instructions
for Grounding them in the True Protestant
Religion."](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/ProtestantTutor.png/170px-
ProtestantTutor.png)](/wiki/File:ProtestantTutor.png)

[](/wiki/File:ProtestantTutor.png "Enlarge")

[Benjamin Harris's](/wiki/Benjamin_Harris_\(publisher\) "Benjamin Harris
\(publisher\)") _Protestant Tutor_ , a primer popular for decades and the
source for the _[New England Primer](/wiki/New_England_Primer "New England
Primer")_. Edition of 1713. Hanoverian propaganda extended to books for
children's education.

Anne was predeceased by Sophia, Electress Dowager of Hanover, and was
therefore succeeded by the latter's son, who became [George
I](/wiki/George_I_of_Great_Britain "George I of Great Britain") in 1714.

Attempts were made in the [risings of 1715 and 1745](/wiki/Jacobite_risings
"Jacobite risings") to restore Stuart claimants to the Throne, supported by
those who recognised the [Jacobite succession](/wiki/Jacobite_succession
"Jacobite succession"). The [House of Hanover](/wiki/House_of_Hanover "House
of Hanover") nonetheless remained undeposed, and the Crown descended in
accordance with the appointed rules. In 1801, following the [Acts of Union
1800](/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1800 "Acts of Union 1800"), the separate crowns of
Great Britain and Ireland were merged and became the [United Kingdom of Great
Britain and Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United
Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland"). Between 1811 and 1820, when [George
III](/wiki/George_III "George III") was deemed unfit to rule, the Prince of
Wales (later [George IV](/wiki/George_IV "George IV")) acted as his
[regent](/wiki/Regency_era "Regency era"). Some years later the [Regency Act
1830](/wiki/Regency_Act_1830 "Regency Act 1830") made provision for a change
in the line of succession had a child been born to [William
IV](/wiki/William_IV_of_the_United_Kingdom "William IV of the United Kingdom")
after his death, but this event did not come about.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Coronation_of_George_VI_1937.jpg/170px-
Coronation_of_George_VI_1937.jpg)](/wiki/File:Coronation_of_George_VI_1937.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Coronation_of_George_VI_1937.jpg "Enlarge")

George VI receiving [homage](/wiki/Homage_\(feudal\) "Homage \(feudal\)") at
his [coronation](/wiki/Coronation_of_King_George_VI_and_Queen_Elizabeth
"Coronation of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth") in 1937

In 1936 [Edward VIII](/wiki/Edward_VIII "Edward VIII") abdicated 11 months
after he succeeded to the throne immediately on his father's death. Edward was
proclaimed King in January 1936,[10] and opened (for the only time) Parliament
in November 1936. Edward VIII had desired to marry [Wallis
Simpson](/wiki/Wallis_Simpson "Wallis Simpson"), a divorcee, but the [Church
of England](/wiki/Church_of_England "Church of England"), of which the British
Sovereign is Supreme Governor, would not authorize the marriage of divorcees.
Consequently, Parliament passed [His Majesty's Declaration of Abdication Act
1936](/wiki/His_Majesty%27s_Declaration_of_Abdication_Act_1936 "His Majesty's
Declaration of Abdication Act 1936"), by which Edward VIII ceased to be
Sovereign "immediately upon" his royal assent as King being signified in
Parliament on 11 December. The Act provided that he and his descendants, if
any, were not to have any "right, title or interest in or to the succession to
the Throne". Edward died childless in 1972.

Edward's abdication was "a [demise of the Crown](/wiki/Demise_of_the_Crown
"Demise of the Crown")" (in the words of the Act), and the [Duke of
York](/wiki/Duke_of_York#Seventh_creation,_1920–1936 "Duke of York"), his
brother who was then next in the line, immediately succeeded to the throne and
to its "rights, privileges, and dignities", taking the [regnal
name](/wiki/Regnal_name "Regnal name") [George VI](/wiki/George_VI "George
VI"). He in turn was succeeded in 1952 by his own elder daughter, [Elizabeth
II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II"). By that time the monarch of the United
Kingdom no longer reigned in the greater part of Ireland (which had become a
[republic](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland") in 1949), but was
the monarch of a number of independent sovereign states (Commonwealth realms).

### Commonwealth realms

Further information: [Perth Agreement](/wiki/Perth_Agreement "Perth
Agreement")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Coronation_of_Queen_Elizabeth_II_Couronnement_de_la_Reine_Elizabeth_II.jpg/170px-
Coronation_of_Queen_Elizabeth_II_Couronnement_de_la_Reine_Elizabeth_II.jpg)](/wiki/File:Coronation_of_Queen_Elizabeth_II_Couronnement_de_la_Reine_Elizabeth_II.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Coronation_of_Queen_Elizabeth_II_Couronnement_de_la_Reine_Elizabeth_II.jpg
"Enlarge")

Elizabeth II at her coronation in 1953, passing to the left of the [Coronation
Chair](/wiki/Coronation_Chair "Coronation Chair")

Each of the Commonwealth realms has the same person as monarch and, to
maintain that arrangement, they have agreed to continue the same line of
succession; some realms do so through domestic succession laws, while others
stipulate whoever is monarch of the United Kingdom will also be monarch of
that realm. In February 1952, on her accession, Elizabeth II [was
proclaimed](/wiki/Proclamation_of_accession_of_Elizabeth_II "Proclamation of
accession of Elizabeth II") as sovereign separately throughout her realms. In
October 2011, the heads of government of all 16 realms agreed unanimously at a
[meeting](/wiki/Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government_Meeting_2011 "Commonwealth
Heads of Government Meeting 2011") held in Perth, Australia, to proposed
changes to the royal succession laws that would see the order of succession
for people born after 28 October 2011 governed by absolute
primogeniture—wherein succession passes to an individual's children according
to birth order, regardless of gender—instead of male-preference primogeniture.
They also agreed to lift a ban on those who marry Roman Catholics. The ban on
Catholics themselves was retained to ensure that the monarch would be in
communion with the [Church of England](/wiki/Church_of_England "Church of
England").[11] The changes came into effect across the Commonwealth realms on
26 March 2015, after legislation was made according to each realm's
constitution.[12][13]

Following the changes coming into effect, the positions of the first 27 in
line remained unchanged, including Princess Anne and her children and
grandchildren, until the birth of Princess Charlotte of Cambridge on 2 May
2015. The first to be affected by the changes, on the day they came into
effect in March, were the children of Lady Davina Lewis—her son Tāne (born
2012) and her daughter Senna (born 2010)—who were reversed in the order of
succession, becoming 29th and 28th in line respectively.[14]

## Current rules

The Bill of Rights and the Act of Settlement (restated by the Acts of Union)
still govern succession to the throne. They were amended in the United Kingdom
by the [Succession to the Crown Act
2013](/wiki/Succession_to_the_Crown_Act_2013 "Succession to the Crown Act
2013"), which was passed mainly "to make succession to the Crown not depend on
gender" and "to make provision about Royal Marriages" (according to its [long
title](/wiki/Long_title "Long title")), thereby implementing the [Perth
Agreement](/wiki/Perth_Agreement "Perth Agreement") in the UK and in those
realms that, by their laws, have as their monarch automatically whoever is
monarch of the UK. Other realms passed their own legislation.

Anyone ineligible to succeed is treated as if they were "dead". That
individual's descendants are not also disqualified, unless they are personally
ineligible.

### Marriages

The [Act of Settlement 1701](/wiki/Act_of_Settlement_1701 "Act of Settlement
1701") provides that Protestant "[heirs of the body](/wiki/Heirs_of_the_body
"Heirs of the body")" (that is, legitimate descendants) of [Sophia, Electress
of Hanover](/wiki/Sophia,_Electress_of_Hanover "Sophia, Electress of
Hanover"), are eligible to succeed to the throne, unless otherwise
disqualified. The meaning of _heir of the body_ is determined by the common
law rules of male preference [primogeniture](/wiki/Primogeniture
"Primogeniture") (the "male-preference" criterion is no longer applicable, in
respect of succession to the throne, to persons born after 28 October 2011),
whereby older children and their descendants inherit before younger children,
and a male child takes precedence over a female sibling.[15] Children born out
of wedlock and adopted children are not eligible to succeed. Illegitimate
children whose parents subsequently marry are legitimated, but remain
ineligible to inherit the Crown.[n 4]

The [Royal Marriages Act 1772](/wiki/Royal_Marriages_Act_1772 "Royal Marriages
Act 1772") (repealed by the Succession to the Crown Act 2013) further required
descendants of [George II](/wiki/George_II_of_Great_Britain "George II of
Great Britain") to obtain the consent of the reigning monarch to marry. (The
requirement did not apply to descendants of princesses who married into
foreign families, as well as, from 1936, any descendants of Edward VIII,[n 5]
of which there are none.) The Act provided, however, that if a
[dynast](/wiki/Dynasty#Dynasts "Dynasty") older than twenty-five years
notified the Privy Council of his or her intention to marry without the
consent of the Sovereign, then he or she may have lawfully done so after one
year, unless both houses of Parliament expressly disapproved of the marriage.
A marriage that contravened the Royal Marriages Act was void, and the
resulting offspring illegitimate and thus ineligible to succeed, though the
succession of the dynast who failed to obtain consent was not itself affected.
This also had the consequence that marriage to a Roman Catholic without
permission was void, so that the dynast was not disqualified from succeeding
on account of being married to a Roman Catholic. Thus when the future [George
IV](/wiki/George_IV_of_the_United_Kingdom "George IV of the United Kingdom")
attempted to marry the Roman Catholic [Maria
Fitzherbert](/wiki/Maria_Anne_Fitzherbert "Maria Anne Fitzherbert") in 1785
without obtaining permission from [George
III](/wiki/George_III_of_the_United_Kingdom "George III of the United
Kingdom") he did not disqualify himself from inheriting the throne in due
course.[2] A marriage voided by the 1772 act prior to its repeal remains void
"for all purposes relating to the succession to the Crown" under the 2013
act.[16]

The constitutional crisis arising from Edward VIII's decision to marry a
divorcee in 1936 led to [His Majesty's Declaration of Abdication Act
1936](/wiki/His_Majesty%27s_Declaration_of_Abdication_Act_1936 "His Majesty's
Declaration of Abdication Act 1936"), which provided that Edward VIII and his
descendants would have no claim to the throne.[17] The Act is no longer
applicable, because Edward died in 1972 without issue.

Under the 2013 Succession to the Crown Act, the first six persons in line to
the throne must obtain the sovereign's approval before marrying.[16] Marriage
without the Sovereign's consent disqualifies the person and the person's
descendants from the marriage from succeeding to the Crown,[16] but the
marriage is still legally valid.

### Religion

Rules relating to eligibility established by the Bill of Rights are retained
under the Act of Settlement. The preamble to the Act of Settlement notes that
the Bill of Rights provides "that all and every person and persons that then
[at the time of the Bill of Right's passage] were, or afterwards should be
reconciled to, or shall hold communion with the [See or Church of
Rome](/wiki/Holy_See "Holy See"), or should profess the popish religion, or
marry a papist, should be excluded."[18] The Act of Settlement continues,
providing "that all and every Person and Persons who shall … is, are or shall
be reconciled to or shall hold Communion with the See or Church of Rome or
shall profess the Popish religion or shall marry a papist shall be subject to
such Incapacities"[19] as the Bill of Rights established.

The precise meaning of the aforementioned clauses is subject to contention.
Under one interpretation, the religion of an individual at the precise moment
of succession is relevant. Under another interpretation, anyone who has been a
Roman Catholic at any time since 1689 ("then … or afterwards") is forever
ineligible to succeed. The former interpretation allows a Roman Catholic to
convert to Protestantism and succeed to the Throne just before a vacancy on
the throne occurs devolving the crown on the first dynast in the line of
succession; the latter does not. In either case, however, other denominations
of faith are not affected; it is clear that any non-Catholic may convert to
Protestantism and succeed to the Throne. It is a requirement that the monarch
must be a Protestant.[1]

The Act of Settlement further provided that anyone who married a Roman
Catholic was ineligible to succeed. The Act did not require that the spouse be
Protestant; it only barred those who marry Roman Catholics. Since the passage
of the Act it has been determined (in the case of [Prince Edward, Duke of
Kent](/wiki/Prince_Edward,_Duke_of_Kent "Prince Edward, Duke of Kent")) that
an individual is not barred because his or her spouse later converts to Roman
Catholicism after their marriage. The Succession to the Crown Act 2013 removed
the bar on individuals married to Roman Catholics, though not on Roman
Catholics themselves.

### Treason

Under the [Treason Act 1702](/wiki/Treason_Act_1702 "Treason Act 1702") and
the Treason (Ireland) Act 1703, it is
[treason](/wiki/High_treason_in_the_United_Kingdom "High treason in the United
Kingdom") to "endeavour to deprive or hinder any person who shall be the next
in succession to the crown ... from succeeding ... to the imperial crown of
this realm". Since the [Crime and Disorder Act
1998](/wiki/Crime_and_Disorder_Act_1998 "Crime and Disorder Act 1998"), the
maximum penalty has been life imprisonment.

## Accession

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/St_Jamess_Palace.jpg/170px-
St_Jamess_Palace.jpg)](/wiki/File:St_Jamess_Palace.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:St_Jamess_Palace.jpg "Enlarge")

The Accession Council normally meets in [St James's
Palace](/wiki/St_James%27s_Palace "St James's Palace") to proclaim the new
sovereign.

In the Commonwealth realms, upon the death of a sovereign, the heir apparent
or heir presumptive succeeds to the throne immediately, with no need for
confirmation or further ceremony.[20][n 6] Nevertheless, the [Accession
Council](/wiki/Accession_Council "Accession Council") meets and decides upon
the making of the accession proclamation, which by custom has for centuries
been ceremonially proclaimed in public places, in London, [York](/wiki/York
"York"), [Edinburgh](/wiki/Edinburgh "Edinburgh") and other cities. The
anniversary is observed throughout the sovereign's reign as [Accession
Day](/wiki/Accession_Day "Accession Day"), including royal [gun
salutes](/wiki/Gun_salutes "Gun salutes") in the United Kingdom.[22]

Formerly, a new sovereign proclaimed his or her own accession. But on the
death of Elizabeth I an Accession Council met to proclaim the accession of
James I to the throne of England. James was then in Scotland and reigning as
King James VI of Scotland. This precedent has been followed since. Now, the
Accession Council normally meets in [St James's
Palace](/wiki/St_James%27s_Palace "St James's Palace"). Proclamations since
James I's have usually been made in the name of the [Lords
Spiritual](/wiki/Lords_Spiritual "Lords Spiritual") and
[Temporal](/wiki/Lords_Temporal "Lords Temporal"), the [Privy
Council](/wiki/Privy_Council_of_the_United_Kingdom "Privy Council of the
United Kingdom"), the [Lord Mayor](/wiki/Lord_Mayor_of_the_City_of_London
"Lord Mayor of the City of London"), [Aldermen](/wiki/Alderman "Alderman") and
citizens of the [City of London](/wiki/City_of_London "City of London") and
"other principal [Gentlemen](/wiki/Gentleman "Gentleman") of quality", though
there have been variations in some proclamations. The proclamation of
accession of Elizabeth II was the first to make mention of representatives of
members of the [Commonwealth](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of
Nations").

Upon his or her accession, a new sovereign is required by law to make and
subscribe several oaths. The Bill of Rights of 1689 first required the
sovereign to make a public declaration of non-belief in Roman Catholicism.[n
7] This declaration, known as the [Accession
Declaration](/wiki/Accession_Declaration "Accession Declaration"), is required
to be taken at either the first meeting of parliament of his or her reign
(i.e. during the [State Opening of
Parliament](/wiki/State_Opening_of_Parliament "State Opening of Parliament"))
or at his or her coronation, whichever occurs first. The current wording of
this declaration was adopted in 1910 as the previous wording was deemed to be
controversial and overtly anti-Catholic. Rather than denouncing Roman
Catholicism, the sovereign now declares him or herself to be a Protestant and
that he or she will "uphold and maintain" the Protestant succession.[23] In
addition to the Accession Declaration, the new sovereign is required by the
Acts of Union 1707 to make an oath to "maintain and preserve" the Church of
Scotland.[24] This oath is normally made at the sovereign's first meeting of
the Privy Council following his or her accession. According to the [Regency
Act 1937](/wiki/Regency_Act_1937 "Regency Act 1937"), should the sovereign be
under the age of 18, such oaths and declarations required to be taken by the
sovereign shall be made upon his attainment of that age.[25]

After a period of mourning,[26] the new sovereign is usually [consecrated and
crowned](/wiki/Coronation_of_the_British_monarch "Coronation of the British
monarch") in [Westminster Abbey](/wiki/Westminster_Abbey "Westminster Abbey").
Normally, the [Archbishop of Canterbury](/wiki/Archbishop_of_Canterbury
"Archbishop of Canterbury") officiates, though the sovereign may designate any
other bishop of the [Church of England](/wiki/Church_of_England "Church of
England"). A coronation is not necessary for a sovereign to reign; for
example, [Edward VIII](/wiki/Edward_VIII "Edward VIII") was never crowned, yet
during his short reign was the undoubted king.
